awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Distributed Network Optimization and Consensus with Event-Driven Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to develop techniques to allow multiple decision makers to jointly solve optimization and learning problems through individual computations and with limited communications among the decision makers contributing to an area known as distributed optimization and learning. Here, each decision maker is viewed as an intelligent agent, modeled as a node in a network of agents. Communication between the agents can occur only if their nodes are connected by a link of the network graph. This framework allows modeling of large systems consisting of multiple agents where each agent collects data from the environment as well as from its neighboring agents.  The agents process the received data and communicate with one another over time. This research project aims to extend existing knowledge by reducing the requirement that nodes must communicate acknowledgments from neighboring nodes and reducing the amount of communication by using event-driven communications, where communication between neighboring nodes is triggered by the occurrence of pre-defined events. Applications considered include networks of unmanned aerial vehicles and electric power grids. The project will provide an impact on students at the university and through outreach to local high schools.


The research project will pose novel problems for distributed networks of communicating agents tasked with achieving goals defined globally while using limited communication. The project also aims to define new applications-motivated distributed network problems, to make theoretical headway on these problems, and to pursue several applications of the theory in detail. A main goal of this work is to extend existing algorithms to the event-triggered framework. These events can be defined in terms of local system variables meeting certain conditions, or as arrival events where certain types of information are received from the external environment. The research project will model both types of events as well as their influence on the dynamics of distributed decision making. For exogenous arriving information, the researchers will consider occasional arrivals of exogenous data at a smaller set of specialized nodes. Stability of the designed distributed algorithms will be analyzed relative to the arrival processes, the network dynamics, and the graph structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project made fundamental contributions that provide new insights, concepts and methods on control and optimization of networked dynamic systems. The approach taken aims at addressing major difficulties with existing methods of learning, optimization and control of networked systems while maintaining privacy and simultaneously reducing computational requirements. The project addressed Federated Learning, Differential Privacy, analysis of Reservoir Computing, and modeling and analysis of Dynamic Mode Decomposition with Control for systems with and without delays.

 

Federated Learning (FL), introduced in 2017, focuses on building generalized models for a network of agents over a distributed data set while attempting to ensure data privacy for participating clients. FL has in part been driven by cultural shifts toward data privacy. FL is having great impact in many technological and social network applications. Contributions of significance in Federated Learning can have far-reaching impact. We developed a new direction in the area of Federated Learning aiming to alleviate the difficulty faced by traditional (gradient-based) algorithms in accommodating system and statistical heterogeneity. More specifically, we introduced a new FL methodology based on Bayesian Inference, which we refer to as Federated Inference (FedInfer). FedInfer is a novel approach to FL in which the server takes greater advantage of available computational power. We have analyzed the approach and made calculations that demonstrate improved performance of FedInfer over other brands of FL. By taking advantage of the communication delay inherent in distributed systems, the proposed FedInfer method makes smarter update steps between communication rounds. We studied the performance of a Federated Learning system equipped with a Bayesian Optimization agent on the server and compared it against existing FL solutions. We demonstrated the method's usefulness in addressing major challenges in FL, and suggested how the results can be further improved. 

 

As noted above, FL is linked with a desire to maintain client privacy. This motivated us to work toward strengthening existing work on differential privacy, aiming to achieve a method that is not only “approximately differentially private,” but indeed “exactly differentially private” (these have technical definitions, but suffice it to say that exact differential privacy is preferable to approximate differential privacy. The main construct in our approach to this subject is presenting a novel analysis of the Symmetric alpha-Stable (SaS) mechanism and its application to differential privacy. We pursued research to study the degree of privacy that is achieved when Federated Learning is invoked for reservoir computing. Federated Reservoir Computing allows multiple parties to collaboratively train a reservoir-based model while ostensibly providing privacy guarantees for participating clients. We also performed initial studies in control of power grids with high penetration of renewable energy resources. The variability of the renewable resources (like solar and wind generators) introduces new challenges in power system control, which we addressed via predictive control methods.

 

We investigated online learning of multiple fractional delays for networked control systems and developing controllers that use online delay estimation in feedback control laws. This work produced a method that can achieve performance similar to that for a system without delays. The work involves use of dynamic mode decomposition (DMD) and what we view as a natural extension to DMD, which we coined Dynamic Mode Decomposition with Control (DMDc). We initiated work toward merging our DMDc work with our Federated Learning contributions.
